title: Boris Johnson’s election dilemma
text:
When will the U.K. get an election?

With the EU expected to grant a Brexit delay, Boris Johnson has two options. Either he can abandon the push to get his Brexit deal passed into U.K. law now and go to the polls on the basis that MPs are blocking him from delivering Brexit. Or he could try and strike a deal with Labour on a new timetable to get his Brexit deal through parliament before pushing for a vote. Whenever he chooses, of course, he'll need a majority of MPs to agree to call a vote.

In part, his decision will rest on the length of the delay offered by Brussels. European Council President Donald Tusk has urged EU27 leaders to grant the U.K.'s formal request for an extension until January 31, with the possibility of leaving sooner if the Withdrawal Agreement is ratified by the U.K. and European parliaments. He has the support of the European Parliament, Ireland and Germany, but at a meeting of EU diplomats in Brussels on Wednesday afternoon, France was pushing for a shorter extension, diplomats said. The EU has yet to announce a new deadline.

The timing of any election will also have significant implications on the positioning of the two main parties, and both are split about which scenario would play most to their advantage.

So far, Johnson has appeared most tempted by the first option. His spokesman this week has given bullish briefings that “this broken parliament will always vote for delay rather than a deal,” suggesting that as soon as the EU grants an extension, he will call an election.

"How much does not delivering Brexit by October 31 hurt Boris Johnson? We just don’t know” — Anthony Wells, director of YouGov’s political polling

But polling experts doubt this is the safest bet for the prime minister and today the Johnson-supporting Sun newspaper argued in a leader column that he shouldn't be tempted by a quick poll. “The Tories have a decent lead in the polls depending on which pollsters you look at, but the question is how well that translates into seats,” said Anthony Wells, director of YouGov’s political polling.

If the Remain vote splits between Labour and the Liberal Democrats, that could benefit the Tories, but if the two parties do well in different places, “even quite a big Conservative lead could end up not translating into a particularly good result,” he said.

“The second question is, how much does not delivering Brexit by October 31 hurt Boris Johnson? We just don’t know.”

The Tories have their eye on Labour-held, Brexit-voting seats in the north, but it’s not clear if they can win them. “It’s hard territory for them,” Wells said. In seats such as Mansfield, which the Tories took off Labour last time, “there were demographic movements on their side anyway,” with populations that are becoming older and more middle class.

Tim Bale, professor of politics at Queen Mary University, said that by triggering an election before he has delivered Brexit, Johnson “runs the risk of Nigel Farage telling the country that this isn’t really Brexit and that he might not get it anyway.”

“If he’s actually got the Withdrawal Bill through, Farage may criticize the kind of Brexit that Boris Johnson has achieved, but it will be very difficult to argue to voters that Brexit hasn’t happened,” Bale said. He suggested that missing the October 31 deadline may not damage Johnson much if he uses the extra time to get his deal through. “Competence is a very big factor in British elections, and being seen to have delivered on a promise — albeit a few weeks late — will be a massive advantage to Boris Johnson.”

Ultimately, according to Bale, voters who are planning to vote Tory “just want to ‘get Brexit done’ — and they will reward the person who has done that for them.”

David Herszenhorn and Jacopo Barigazzi contributed reporting.

description: Polling suggests the UK prime minister might be wise to get his Brexit deal through before a vote.
